audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker greeting listeners on Anzac Day weekend, mentioning he is out camping. He describes his activity, focusing on looking for "flower gold" and preferring crevices for finding more gold. The speaker transitions to describing his strategy for gold prospecting. Throughout the clip, ambient sounds suggest an outdoor environment.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing the mud deposits left by recent floods. He then mentions cleaning at the start and how the runoff goes into a sandbar, which he plans to follow. There is also a distinct sound of flowing water in the background, suggesting a river or stream environment, further supported by the speaker's mention of mud deposits and a sandbar.

The clip begins with a male speaker describing putting buckets of something, possibly dirt or rocks, into crevasses, which he notes are easy to find empty but hard to find full. He mentions stockpiling the material to run it through later, explaining that this method keeps water away from his work area and saves petrol. There is some background noise and possible sound of breath. The speaker is speaking casually.

The audio clip features a single male speaker. He begins by discussing the past few days, mentioning it may be the "fourth," and then describes cleaning out crevices, noting he "did pretty good." He highlights finding gold, even saying he got more gold out of a tiny crevice compared to all of the others. In the background, there are wind sounds, which contribute to the sense of an outdoor environment.

The clip begins with a male speaker explaining something is the main reason for something else. The tone is explanatory and outdoorsy. He points out "this is mostly bedrock" and indicates the drainage point is right here. He explains how everything washes up, pointing to debris from a flood as evidence of high water levels. Then the sound of wind rushes in as the speaker continues, stating everything runs down through into that hole.

The audio clip features a single male speaker, expressing that finding "little tiny spots" leads to finding gold, and mentioning his "highbanker" and its replacement. He comments on the unexpected weight of a "bangow" and praises his Chinese pump, noting its reliable performance despite an oil cap issue. The man then anticipates returning in a few days. Ambient sounds of running water persist in the background, suggesting the speaker is working near a stream or river.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker expressing interest in the extent of a crevice, saying he "won't dig too far." He mentions digging previously, taking him five minutes to find little gold. The speaker's tone is casual and reflective as he outlines his plan to clean the crevice and investigate rocks where someone else has already been. The audio ends with the male speaker confirming he will get into that task.

The audio begins with a male speaker, in a casual and somewhat conversational tone, mentioning "we can't just next door". He then marvels at a "big carp" in the creek, emphasizing its size, and notes the beautiful weather as they approach winter. He suggests returning after cleaning something out to see how they went. This speaking is followed by music that seems to be of an electronic or synthesized nature, creating a somber mood.  The audio clip concludes with music.

The clip begins with one male speaker describing the physical setting as getting "pretty deep down in that crevice." He describes how he is using equipment, including an extendable shovel, humorously noting its possible origin from his mother's shed. Intermittently, there is the distinct sound of water and shifting gravel, which suggests he might be panning or sifting through materials, likely near a water source. He reflects finding "a nice little picketer yesterday." There is further discussion around changing hands and continuing the process, along with continued water and gravel sounds, before the speaker states "it is chockers" and explains that this is "a more productive way" while hoping the viewer will see the results. As he continues panning, he states "at least 50" which can be inferred as specs of gold, followed by an attempt to show what he found, noting that the camera doesn't zoom in.

The clip begins with the sound of shoveling. A single male speaker notes about the material in a pile and that the location they're digging isn't likely to have as much richness at the bottom. He adds, "That's the way to go," and expresses uncertainty whether his work is showing up on camera. He then remarks on the presence of big bits with "tons of fine stuff," and discusses a big crevice that runs uphill and hopes that there is not too much over burden. The man describes the area as an inside bend of a flood and notes anything gets washed up there.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing how water will "find its way" into a crevice. He mentions cleaning out a "little one." He then explains the process as "increasing your chances of getting good gold." The audio clip concludes with a sound that could be described as a "ding."

The audio clip starts with a male speaker talking about putting "tons and tons and tons of sand" through a place like this. He mentions working in "big cracks and crevices". Then, he says "All right, so I'll keep going" and that he will "come back to you when I'm running the high banker." Throughout the clip, there is background environmental noise.

The audio clip features a single male speaker who seems to be outdoors, judging by his comments. He sounds somewhat out of breath as he notes that he's "finished working out those crevices" and acknowledges their "unbelievably deep" nature. He anticipates returning to the task tomorrow, mentioning a sandbar, and expresses his hope that it will be alright. The clip ends with a sound resembling a sniff or exhale.

The audio clip begins with sounds indicating movement, possibly someone walking through an outdoor environment. These sounds are accompanied by speech; a male voice expresses effort or strain as he examines something, stating "have a look in the bank." He then identifies "definitely gold in there," followed by a suggestion to "pull it down, come back and see what we got." Throughout this section, background noises are present, possibly wind or rustling sounds, contributing to an outdoor or natural setting.
